awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2018
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2018, Broadening Participation of Groups Under-represented in Biology. The fellowship supports a research and training plan for the Fellow that will increase the participation of groups underrepresented in biology. The research plan focuses on the evolution of animal weapons (e.g., antlers, horns), which are among the most extreme traits in the animal world. These weapons are often massive in size and grow drastically out of proportion with the body. It is therefore unsurprising that they have captured the attention of biologists for centuries, since understanding more about extreme weapons sheds light on many peculiar biological activities. Yet, despite such intense interest, surprisingly little is known about how these traits evolve. In particular, 3 questions need to be addressed: How do weapons evolve to such extreme sizes? What are the scenarios that favor weapon evolution? And what genes underlie the evolution of these traits? The research plan directly addresses these questions by exploring the evolution, ecology, and genetics of extreme animal weapons.

Specifically, the research plan takes an integrative approach to elucidate the evolution, ecology, and genetic regulation of extreme morphology through the study of animal weapons. The program is centered around the model weapon system Gnatocerus cornutus (broad horned flour beetles) and contains 3 research objectives: (1) determine the evolvability of extreme morphology by using artificial selection to develop lineages with divergent weapon phenotypes, (2) measure the fitness consequences of variation in weapon size by exposing these experimental lineages to ecological and social condition hypothesized to influence the evolution of selected morphology and (3) identify the genetic basis of weapon growth through QTL (quantitative trait locus) mapping of derived lineages produced via artificial selection. The fellowship also supports an associated outreach plan specifically aimed at boarding participation of underrepresented groups in biology. The outreach plan contains two objectives: (1) recruit undergraduate students from underrepresented groups and train them in all aspects of the cross-disciplinary research plan and (2) develop workshops to train and equip secondary school teachers to conduct artificial selection experiments on weapons in the classroom. Together, the research and outreach objectives provide the Fellow with extensive training in multivariate selection experiments, and the association mapping of complex traits. In addition, the Fellow also receives training in how to effectively mentor undergraduates from diverse populations and how to develop and execute productive outreach programs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Many traits in nature are highly dependent on the juvenile environment in which an organism develops. Food availability at a young age has a profound impact on the size, shape, and the behavior of organisms as they grow older. However, differences in adult traits that result from differences in juvenile nutrition can be subtle and difficult to observe. This project aimed to uncover the subtle genetic and developmental mechanisms that regulate the interaction between juvenile nutritive environment and adult characteristics. To do this, we focused on a set of phenotypically plastic traits (those traits that are exceptionally sensitive to the environment). This included the phenotypically plastic mandible weapons of broad horned flour beetles (Gnathocerus cornutus) and the phenotypically plastic wings of red-shouldered soapberry bugs (Jadera haematoloma). Both traits show immense variation in adulthood that results from the juvenile environment in which they develop, and the genetic and developmental mechanisms that regulate this link between juvenile environment and adult characteristics are those same mechanisms that regulate that same link in countless other organisms, including humans. These highly sensitive weapons and wings therefore act as a magnifying glass. They expose the otherwise subtle mechanisms of growth that connect juveniles and adults, allowing for in-depth study of these mechanisms both within our study species and across the tree of life.    

 

Research objectives were focused primarily on investigating the evolution of the genetic and developmental mechanisms that link juvenile nutrition and adult structure in the board horned flour beetle. Through a process called artificial selection - where evolution is recreated in a highly controlled lab environment – we constructed populations of board horned flour beetles that differed in their sensitivity to juvenile nutrition. This included beetles that were especially sensitive to juvenile nutrition and beetles that were especially resistant to changes in juvenile nutrition. We found that phenotypically plastic adult structures showed little response to our artificial selection regime. This result was consistent with our prediction that the size and shape of plastic structures would be more influenced by environmental nutrition than the genes regulating expression of those structures. We also found that the sensitivity of phenotypically plastic structures did respond to our artificial selection regime, but that influence of environment on the direction and intensity of that response was greater than expected.  

 

DNA was then collected from the divergent populations of board-horned flour beetles and prepared and preserved for future sequencing. This data has the potential to be combined with the newly emergent, red-shouldered soapberry bug genome, which was sequenced alongside the primary goals of this project, to provide a robust analysis of the genetic and developmental mechanisms that regulate the evolution and expression of phenotypically plastic structures.

 

This project also contained several objectives focused on boarding participation of historically underrepresented groups in the sciences. The work carried out as part of this project fully supported 22 full-time undergraduate research assistants. This included 15 women, 15 persons who identified with minority populations in the United States, five international students, and two students who disclosed their participation in additional programs to aid the involvement of underrepresented groups in the sciences. These students were involved in every stage of the project and were provided with the opportunity to conduct partially or fully independent research projects falling within the scope of the broader aims of this award. Participation provided students with a unique and practical educational opportunity focused largely on critical thinking and experimental design, data analysis and interpretation, drafting of manuscripts and preparation of presentations for international scientific conferences, and the development of practical skills in microbiology and bioinformatics. 

 

Overall, this award provided significant insight into how the genetic and developmental connections between juvenile nutrition and adult characteristics evolve, while at the same time laying the groundwork for robust and in-depth genomic analysis of these same processes. The weapons and wings studied here allowed us to zoom in on this process and shed light on how restriction of juvenile nutrition influences development and genetic expression, the impact starvation may have on adult morphology, and the mechanisms of growth and developmental that may be altered in common nutritive based juvenile disorders. Furthermore, the project supported and trained a diverse group of undergraduate research assistants, jumpstarting their careers as early scientists and preparing them for rigorous exploration in the fields of evolution, genetics, developmental biology, and medicine.
